title: Language Model Re-rankers are Steered by Lexical Similarities
author: Lovisa Hagström (Chalmers University of Technology, University of Gothenburg), Ercong Nie (LMU Munich, Munich Center for Machine Learning), Ruben Halifa (amass technologies), Helmut Schmid (LMU Munich), Richard Johansson (Chalmers University of Technology, University of Gothenburg), Alexander Junge (amass technologies), ...
relevance_why: The paper investigates the performance of language model re-rankers which may inform methodologies for improving audio-language models through better retrieval strategies for audio captions and generation tasks.
background: Evaluating the effectiveness of language model re-rankers for refining retrieval results in Retrieval-Augmented Generation contexts, aiming to enhance information accuracy from various datasets.
contribution: The study introduces a novel separation metric to assess the performance of language model re-rankers, illustrating their challenges with distractors and context absence leading to misidentification of relevant passages.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous evaluations did not thoroughly consider the specific challenges posed by distractors and context in language model performance.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances understanding by applying a separation metric revealing when models fall short and addressing their limitations.

key_innovation: Develops a separation metric that quantifies the differences in relevancy between gold passages and potential distractors.
real_world_impact: The findings suggest the need for adversarial datasets that reflect real-world complexity, potentially guiding the development of more robust machine learning models in various applications, including audio processing.
limitations: The dataset used lacks a focus on lexical similarity preference, possibly skewing the performance analysis of re-rankers.

new_terms.Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): **Retrieval-Augmented Generation** refers to a framework that enhances text generation by retrieving external information to provide responses, which helps in enriching the factual grounding of outputs.
new_terms.separation metric: **Separation metric** is a new evaluation metric developed to assess the ability of models to distinguish between relevant and distractor passages based on their similarity scores.
